Description: Description of cover crop.
Common name for categories of cover crops.
Plant common name as used when cover cropping.

Variable: cv, var, or ssp to specify
Description: Recommended cultivars, varieties, or subspecies of a plant that should be additionally specified for different regions.
Units/Details: list of strings separated by commas

Description: Family common name.
Values: [Grass family, Nonlegumes, Legumes, Mustard family, Aster family, Pea family, Buckwheat family, Flax family, Borage family]

Description: Family scientific name.
Values: [Poaceae, Brassicaceae, Asteraceae, Fabaceae, Polgonaceae, Linaceae, Boraginaceae]

Description: Additional taxonomic details, comments, and issues.
Who put this cover crop on this list?
Full scientific name.
Common region-specific synonyms.
Units/Details: list of strings separated by commas

Description: Should this cover crop be included in the dataset for this zone?
Ability to tolerate drought relative to other species.
Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

Description: Ability to tolerate flood relative to other species.
Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

Description: Ability to tolerate heat relative to other species.
Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

Description: Ability to tolerate poor fertility in general (an amalgamation of low pH soils and/or below-optimum soil tests for N, P, and/or K, sandy soil).
Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

Description: Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Ability to tolerate high salinity relative to other species. Scale 1-5, 1 being least/worst and 5 being most/best.
Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

Description: Ability to tolerate shade relative to other species.
Values: 1 star = none/intolerant, 2 = low, 3 = low-med (cutoff), 4 stars = high-med, 5 = high/tolerant

Description: Likelihood of cover crop survival over the winter.
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Promote Water Quality

Description: Season in which plants have active growth.

C:N ratio is the percentage of organic carbon divided by the percentage of total nitrogen in organic material. Note that the C:N ratio of grasses (warm season annuals) is lower in the vegetative state then in the flowering state.
Values: 1 - Legumes, 2 - Succulent broadleafs, 3 - Woodier broadleafs (sunflowers, annual rye grass), 4 - Cereal grains, 5 - Warm season annuals
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Hinder Crops,Suppress Weeds,Promote Water Quality,Lasting Residue,Improve Soil Organic Matter
Description Notes for Data Verification:
Impacts following goals: Improve soil organic matter, lasting residue, prevent soil erosion, weed suppression.  1 to 5 rating. 

General guide for cover crops at flowering, but there are exceptions: 1 - Legumes 2 - Succulent broadleafs 3 - Woodier broadleafs (sunflowers, annual rye grass) 4 - Cereal grains 5 - Warm season annuals

Description: Amount of dry biomass the cover crop produces in a year, lbs/A.
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Improve Soil Organic Matter,Lasting Residue,Prevent Fall Soil Erosion,Promote Water Quality,Nitrogen Fixation,Nitrogen Scavenging,Hinder Crops,Suppress Weeds
Description Notes for Data Verification: Impacts the following cover cropping goals: improve soil organic matter, lasting residue, prevent soil eriosion, promote water quality, nitrogen fixation, nitrogen scavanging, and weed suppression.

Description: Amount of dry biomass the cover crop produces in a year, lbs/A.
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Improve Soil Organic Matter,Lasting Residue,Prevent Fall Soil Erosion,Promote Water Quality,Nitrogen Fixation,Nitrogen Scavenging,Hinder Crops,Suppress Weeds
Description Notes for Data Verification: Impacts the following cover cropping goals: improve soil organic matter, lasting residue, prevent soil eriosion, promote water quality, nitrogen fixation, nitrogen scavanging, and weed suppression.

Description: Length of time during which the cover crop's entire lifecycle is completed in the selected zone. Cover crops that have different Durations depending on environment or location are reported in order of increasing longevity in nature.
Hessian Fly-Free Date, after which wheat and other grasses can be planted to avoid Hessian fly and/or cereal rust.
Amount of N a legume species contains, lbs/A. This is combined nitrogen fixed plus nitrogen taken up from the soil.
Description Notes for Data Verification: Impacts the following cover cropping goals: nitrogen source

Description: Amount of N a legume species contains, lbs/A. This is combined nitrogen fixed plus nitrogen taken up from the soil.
Description Notes for Data Verification: Impacts the following cover cropping goals: nitrogen source

Description: Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Growth form or predominant shape of an individual plant.
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Suppress Weeds,Promote Water Quality,Prevent Fall Soil Erosion

Description: Whether the cover crop is commonly used in the zone or only beginning to gain adoption.
Cover crop survival under flooding conditions.
The maximum soil pH the cover crop can tolerate, in the top 12 inches of soil, as typically found in the Northeast.
The minimum soil pH, of the top 12 inches of soil, within the plantâ€™s known geographical range.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Level of soil drainage needed for acceptable cover crop growth given regular rainfall.
Values: [Very poorly drained, Poorly drained, Somewhat poorly drained, Moderately well drained, Well drained, Excessively drained, Saturated muck, Well drained muck]

Description: Ability to use (i.e., remove) available soil moisture relative to other species.
Ability to establish and grow in soil with coarse, medium, and fine textured soils given regular rainfall.
Cover crop ability to promote relative activity of mycorrhizal fungi in the rhizosphere.
Speed in the spring at which the cover crop breaks dormancy and grows. No star means that early spring growth is not applicable.
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Nitrogen Scavenging,Nitrogen Fixation,Promote Water Quality

Description:
Degree of difficulty in getting cover crop established.
1 - difficult to establish
5 - very easy to establish

Speed at which the cover crop establishes once planted.
1 - slow to establish
5 - quick to establish
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Fall Soil Erosion,Suppress Weeds,Good Grazing,Nitrogen Scavenging,Promote Water Quality

Description: Details about what triggers flowering: Requires vernalization (spring), Intermediate day (11-13 hrs), Long day (>14 hrs), Based on plant size
Values: [Vernalization, Intermediate Day, Long Day, Plant Size]

Description: Relative ability of cover crop to "mine" P and K from lower soil depths.

Relative length of time that is suitable for growing and terminating a cover crop. For example, cover crops with a very short growing window may be planted and terminated during a very short period (e.g., 6-8 weeks) between cash crops.
Values: [Very Short, Short, Medium, Long, Very Long]

Description: Type of innoculant that needs to applied to legume seed to promote N fixation.
Values: [none, alfalfa, berseem clover, cowpea, crimson clover, lespedeza, lima bean, pea/vetch, pea/vetch/lentil, peanut, red clover, soybean, sweetclover, white clover]

Description: Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Primary root structure: tap or fibrous.
Cover Crop Goals: Prevent Spring Soil Erosion,Reduces Surface Compaction,Penetrates Plow Pan,Promote Water Quality,Prevent Fall Soil Erosion,Increase Soil Aggregation
Description Notes for Data Verification: Impacts the following goals:  Increase soil aggregation, prevent soil erosion, proote water quality, reduces subsurface soil compaction, reduces topsoil compaction

Description: Depth to which the cover crop roots. Considers the relative ability of the roots to grow deeper than the previous crop (to reach residual nitrogen).
Cover Crop Goals: Reduces Surface Compaction,Nitrogen Scavenging,Penetrates Plow Pan,Promote Water Quality
Description Notes for Data Verification: Impacts the following goals: Promote water quality, reduces topsoil compaction, nitrogen scavenging

Description: The base seeding rate (PLS)  represents optimal planting time, optimal termination time, optimal planting method (drilled/cultivate and cultipack), conventional tillage method, no planting green, and no interseeding in a monoculture context. Upper limit (Max) is for intensive activity such as weed suppression or forage.

The base seeding rate (PLS) represents optimal planting time, optimal termination time, optimal planting method (drilled/cultivate and cultipack), conventional tillage method, no planting green, and no interseeding in a monoculture context. Lower limit represents least amount of seed that needs to be planted to achieve the low end of acceptable cover crop performance in a normal to good year (I.e. the cover crop is planted in a timely fashion and there is adequate rainfall and warmth).
Can aerial seeding methods be used for this crop?
Maximum depth to plant seed in fractions of an inch.
Units/Details: inches, down to quarter, half, and eigths

Description: Minimum depth to plant seed in fractions of an inch.
Units/Details: inches, down to quarter, half, and eigths

Description: Cover crop can be broadcast seeded when ground is frozen.
Minimum temperature required for cover crop seed to germinate within 5 days.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Relative cost of seed per pound. One star is least expensive, three stars is most expensive.
Average number of cover crop seeds in a pound of seed.
Likelihood that herbicide application will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Likelihood that herbicide application will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.

Likelihood that conditions below 32 degrees F will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.

5 - Likely to terminate in mild freeze
1 - Requires a very significant freeze to terminate
Values: 5. Likely to terminate in mild freeze 1. Requires a very significant freeze to terminate

Description:
Likelihood that freezing weather conditions will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.

5 - Likely to terminate in mild freeze
1 - Requires a very significant freeze to terminate
Values: 5 likely to terminate in mild freeze  1 requires a very significant freeze to terminate

Description: Likelihood that mowing (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that do not disturb the soil) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.

Likelihood that roller-crimping will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage. Termination is most successful at higher crop densities (3+ tons of dry matter per acre).


Roller crimping is usually used in tandem with chemical termination outside of organic systems.

Likelihood that tillage (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that disturb the soil, as with disking or rotovating) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the flowering stage. The expert group premises that all cover crops can be terminated with tillage, but that 1 represents hard to terminate with tillage and requires an aggressive technique, whereas 5 is easy to terminate with tillage and requires the least aggressive technique. The techniques are categorized as follows.

5-light disk
4-heavy disk
3-chisel plow
2-rototill
1-moldboard

Likelihood that tillage (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that disturb the soil, as with disking or rotovating) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage. The expert group premises that all cover crops can be terminated with tillage, but that 1 represents hard to terminate with tillage and requires an aggressive technique, whereas 5 is easy to terminate with tillage and requires the least aggressive technique. The techniques are categorized as follows.

5-light disk
4-heavy disk
3-chisel plow
2-rototill
1-moldboard
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.

Indicates likelihood that the cover crop seed, once planted, will sit in the soil for an extended time then germinate at an inopportune moment (e.g., during cash crop growth). This is a long-term issue in which the "risk is in the cover crop seed bag".

1= rarely has hard seed, 5=hard seed is a frequent concern.

Risk of previous cover crop volunteering in current cash crop due to management (i.e. the previous cover crop setting seed that becomes part of the soil weed seedbank). Impact depends on crop rotation (i.e. desirability of self-reseeding).

1=rarely volunteers, 5=frequently volunteers
Ability of a cover crop to decrease nematode populations (e.g., trap crop). 1=poor choice for discouraging nematodes, 5=excellent choice
Ability of a cover crop to decrease insect pest populations. 1=poor choice for discouraging insect pests, 5=excellent choice
Comments about specific pests (e.g., which species are promoted/discouraged), edge cases, management suggestions, etc.
Comments about specific pests (e.g., which species are promoted/discouraged), edge cases, management suggestions, etc.

Relative ranking of cover crop impact to promote disease in the following cash crop. 
1 - does not promote disease in following cash crop.
5 - very likely to promote disease in following cash crop.

Ability of a cover crop to increase nematode populations. 
1=does not support nematode populations, 5=excellent for increasing nematode populations
Ability of a cover crop to increase insect pest populations. 1=does not promote insect populations, 5=frequently promotes pest insects

Relative ranking of cover crop impact to suppress disease in the following cash crop. 
1 - does not suppress disease in following cash crop.
5 - very likely to suppress disease in following cash crop.
Ending date when cover crop be planted into standing cash crop.
Starting date when cover crop be planted into standing cash crop.
Broadcast seeding with a tractor in a frozen field. Make sure the ground is frozen enough so tractors do not get stuck. Works best with heavier soils.

Broadcast seeding with a tractor in a frozen field. Make sure snow has melted enough for the seed to benefit from the thaw-freeze process that works the seed into the soil. Works best with heavier soils.

Variable: Second Temperature/Moisture Risk to Establishment End
Second Temperature/Moisture Risk to Establishment Start

Modifier dependent on Optimum or Late Termination

Early, Optimum, or late planting
Early, Optiumum, or Late termination
No-till, reduced till, conventional till

Mixes that this crop is used in.
Weight of each cover crop in the mix (in the same order as listed in Cover Crops in Mix)
List of cover crops used in this mix.
Descriptive and functional mix name.
if this mix is Commercially Available, who sells this mix?
Cover cropping goals this mix is designed to assist with.
Additional details about this mix.
Links to written resources, materials, etc. such as extension bulletins

Contains compounds that inhibit weed seed germination or deter weed growth. 
1=no allelopathy, 5= extremely allelopathic
Can cover crop be planted into standing cash crop.
Cover crop tolerance to being grazed.
Cover crop value for grazing; consider cover crop palatability, toxicity, and monetary value.

Ability to tolerate equipment traffic and withstand harvesting.
1 - Non-tolerant
5 - Extremely tolerant

Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: reduces subsurface soil compaction

Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction in the topsoil layer, roughly the top 0-6" of soil (i.e. the traditional plow layer).

Impacts the following cover cropping goals: reduces topsoil compaction
Likelihood that mowing (i.e. destructive mechanical operations that do not disturb the soil) will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage.

Planting cash crop then immediately terminating cover crop (prior to cash crop emergence). Note: any crop can be planted green with the correct equipment; this column represents general considerations.
Extent to which the cover crop can serve as habitat for pollinators.
Cover crop ability to provide resources needed by beneficial insects (e.g., shelter, nectar)

Likelihood that roller-crimping will successfully terminate the cover crop while it is in the vegetative stage. Termination is most successful at higher crop densities (3+ tons of drymatter per acre).

Roller crimping is usually used in tandem with chemical termination outside of organic systems.
Rate at which cover crop should be planted via Aerial methods. Lower limit is approx 30% ground coverage, upper limit is for intensive activity such as weed suppression or forage.
Rate at which cover crop should be planted via Broadcast methods. Lower limit is approx 30% ground coverage, upper limit is for intensive activity such as weed suppression or forage.

Rate at which cover crop should be planted via Drilled methods in a monoculture context. Lower limit is approx 30% ground coverage, upper limit is for intensive activity such as weed suppression or forage.
Rates how well the cover crop suppresses diseases.
Rates how well the cover crop suppresses diseases.
Rates how well the cover crop suppresses insects, slugs, and other non-weed pests.
Rates how well the cover crop suppresses insects, slugs, and other non-weed pests.
Rates how well the cover crop out-competes weeds by any means through its life cycle, including killed residue.
Rates how well the cover crop out-competes weeds by any means through its life cycle, including killed residue.
If-then statements that outline specific quirks related to cover crop termination.
General cover crop suitability as harvested forage (e.g., haylage).
General cover crop suitability for grazing. See comments for details about suitability for grazing by different types of livestock.
Rates how likely the CC is to interfere with the cash crop (e.g., through creating a poor seed bed, immobilizing soil N, etc.)

Rates cover crop ability to produce organic matter and improve soil structure. Based on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio). Assumes 1) cover crops will be used regularly in the cropping system to provide ongoing additions to soil organic matter and 2) straw is not harvested/removed.
Rates cover crop ability to increase soil aggregation. Prioritizes soil aggregate stability rather than high turnover. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil.
Rates the effectiveness of the cover crop in providing a long-lasting mulch. Based primarily on cover crop tissue quantity (i.e. biomass production) and quality (i.e. C:N ratio).
Rates legume cover crops for their ability to fix N by 50% bloom, which will vary by year and proximity to water/altitude.

Rates cover crop ability to take up and store excess nitrogen. To maximize N scavenging, plant the cover crop as soon as possible after main crop harvest or overseed/interseed into a standing cash crop. Highly-rated cover crops are useful in systems where manure is fall-applied to hold N in place over the winter.
Details about "edge cases", specific cultivars, etc.
Ability of the cover crop to compete with weeds while living for space/nutrients/light/water. Assumes the cover crop is planted early enough in its optimal planting window to generate a dense stand.
Rates cover crop ability to reduce compaction by penetrating the plow pan.
Extent to which the cover crop provides food (i.e. leaves, nectar, pollen) for pollinators.

Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the fall. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.

Ability of a cover crop to prevent soil erosion in the spring. Based on how extensive and how quickly a root system develops, how long residue persists, how well the cover crop holds soil in place against water erosion and the influence the growth habit may have on preventing water erosion.
Improve or maintain water quality. Traits taken into account: N and P scavenging, erosion prevention.

Reduces compaction above the Ap horizon. Better aggregation in clay than sandy soil. Does not necessarily refer to prevention of crusting (use residue, soil aggregation, plant structure to derive). Crusting is only an issue in full tillage systems.
Rates how well the cover crop residue smothers summer annual weeds.
Rates how well the cover crop suppresses winter annual weeds through some combination of competition, residue, and allelopathy.
